elements.content: Hydrothermal reactions of rare earth (Nd, Sm, Eu, and Tb) and l- or d-lactic acid are used to construct four pairs of homochiral metal–organic frameworks (HMOFs) with polymetallic building blocks, namely, {[Nd2(L)2(H2O)3]·4H2O} n (1-r)/(1-s) and {[Ln2(L)2(H2O)2]·4H2O} n {Ln = Sm (2), Eu (3), Tb (4)} ( n-r)/( n-s). The eight complexes were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, infrared spectra, elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis, electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra, and powder X-ray diffraction measurements. The complexes 1–4 featuring a 3D porous metal–organic framework crystallize in chiral space groups, and their chirality is proven by the solid-state ECD spectra. Moreover, the second-harmonic generation (SHG) investigation reveals that the complexes 1-r, 2-r, 3-r, and 4-r have medium SHG eficiencies. The complexes 2, 3, and 4 exhibit relatively high luminescence properties, which could be ascribed to ligand-centered emission. The luminescence of complex 4-r could be quenched by nitrobenzaldehyde, which may be used for molecular sensing and recognition.

The eight complexes were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, infrared spectra, elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis, electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra, and powder X-ray diffraction measurements. Moreover, the second-harmonic generation (SHG) investigation reveals that the complexes 1-r, 2-r, 3-r, and 4-r have medium SHG eficiencies. The complexes 2, 3, and 4 exhibit relatively high luminescence properties, which could be ascribed to ligand-centered emission. The luminescence of complex 4-r could be quenched by nitrobenzaldehyde, which may be used for molecular sensing and recognition.

elements.content: Four pairs of coordination polymers with two chiral centers based on 2,2′-((5-(methoxycarbonyl)-1,3-phenylene)­bis­(oxy))­dipropanoic acid are synthesized and characterized, exhibiting strong characteristic luminescence and identification properties.

elements.content: The rational design and synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) currently attracted great attention due to their tunable structures and versatile properties, which may have potential applications in biological and material science fields. Among the numerous complexes, homochiral metal–organic frameworks (HMOFs) aroused considerable interest recently as potent candidates for enantiomorph recognition and separation, asymmetric catalysis, chiral drug delivery, nonlinear optics (NLO), luminescence, and sensors. Up to now, notable work has been accomplished in the construction and application of HMOFs. Generally, three strategies are widely employed to build HMOFs. As the first strategy, totally achiral components are used to prepare chiral coordination polymers via self-resolution in the crystal growth process. In the second scheme, chiral coordination polymers can also be obtained by the reactions of achiral ligands with metal salts under chiral influence such as templates. The third scheme is to adopt the homochiral ligands as the building blocks to achieve chiral coordination polymers. Compared with the other two strategies, this approach is more effective and feasible and has been widely adopted. As an ideal chiral ligand source, lactic acid is inexpensive and readily available for the construction of HMOFs. At present, most of the reported chiral ligands based on lactic acid contain only one single chiral center, with one lactic acid introduced to the ligand structures. However, more and more effort has been focused on multidentate ligands with more than one chiral center. As part of ongoing HMOF research in our laboratory, it has been found that a V-shaped semirigid linear ligand is unlikely to construct porous frameworks, especially with high dimensionalities. With the aforementioned consideration, a chiral triangular ligand based on 3,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid and lactic acid, namely, 2,2′-((5-(methoxycarbonyl)-1,3-phenylene)­bis­(oxy))­dipropanoic acid (H3L), has been designed and synthesized to build chiral coordination frameworks. The design of H3L is based on the following advantages and considerations: (a) H3L is a tripodal ligand possessing three carboxylate groups with different rigidity, which may be efficient for the construction of fascinating architectures. (b) The presence of chiral pure ligands seems more promising for the expected homochiral MOF formation. (c) The multi-carboxylic acids might have great superiority in constructing chiral coordination frameworks with high dimensionalities and fascinating topologies. The lanthanides with higher coordination numbers and versatile coordination geometries are likely to generate unusual MOF architectures in comparison with transition metals, although the construction process of lanthanide complexes might be difficult to control. We have now successfully prepared four pairs of novel lanthanide HMOF complexes exhibiting two different structure types:{[Nd2(L)2(H2O)3]·4H2O} n (1-r)/(1-s) for type I and {[Ln2(L)2(H2O)2]·4H2O} n {Ln = Sm (2), Eu (3), Tb (4)} ( n-r)/( n-s) for type II. The eight complexes were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, infrared spectra, elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis, electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra, and powder X-ray diffraction measurements. Their luminescence and SHG performance were also investigated.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) currently attracted great attention due to their tunable structures and versatile properties, which may have potential applications in biological and material science fields. Among the numerous complexes, homochiral metal-organic frameworks (HMOFs) aroused considerable interest recently as potent candidates for enantiomorph recognition and separation, asymmetric catalysis, chiral drug delivery, nonlinear optics (NLO), luminescence, and sensors. Up to now, notable work has been accomplished in the construction and application of HMOFs. Generally, three strategies are widely employed to build HMOFs. As the first strategy, totally achiral components are used to prepare chiral coordination polymers via self-resolution in the crystal growth process. In the second scheme, chiral coordination polymers can also be obtained by the reactions of achiral ligands with metal salts under chiral influence such as templates. The third scheme is to adopt the homochiral ligands as the building blocks to achieve chiral coordination polymers. Compared with the other two strategies, this approach is more effective and feasible and has been widely adopted. As an ideal chiral ligand source, lactic acid is inexpensive and readily available for the construction of HMOFs. At present, most of the reported chiral ligands based on lactic acid contain only one single chiral center, with one lactic acid introduced to the ligand structures. However, more and more effort has been focused on multidentate ligands with more than one chiral center. As part of ongoing HMOF research in our laboratory, it has been found that a V-shaped semirigid linear ligand is unlikely to construct porous frameworks, especially with high dimensionalities. With the aforementioned consideration, a chiral triangular ligand based on 3,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid and lactic acid, namely, 2,2'-((5-(methoxycarbonyl)-1,3-phenylene)bis(oxy))dipropanoic acid (H3L), has been designed and synthesized to build chiral coordination frameworks. The design of H3L is based on the following advantages and considerations: (a) H3L is a tripodal ligand possessing three carboxylate groups with different rigidity, which may be efficient for the construction of fascinating architectures. (b) The presence of chiral pure ligands seems more promising for the expected homochiral MOF formation. (c) The multi-carboxylic acids might have great superiority in constructing chiral coordination frameworks with high dimensionalities and fascinating topologies. The lanthanides with higher coordination numbers and versatile coordination geometries are likely to generate unusual MOF architectures in comparison with transition metals, although the construction process of lanthanide complexes might be difficult to control. We have now successfully prepared four pairs of novel lanthanide HMOF complexes exhibiting two different structure types:{[Nd2(L)2(H2O)3]⋅4H2O} n  (1-r)/(1-s) for type I and {[Ln2(L)2(H2O)2]⋅4H2O} n  {Ln = Sm (2), Eu (3), Tb (4)} ( n-r)/( n-s) for type II. The eight complexes were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, infrared spectra, elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis, electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra, and powder X-ray diffraction measurements. Their luminescence and SHG performance were also investigated.

elements.content: The chemical reagents were from Aladdin and used in the reactions without any treatment or purification. A PerkinElmer 2400 elemental analyzer is used for elemental analyses of the compounds. The IR spectra were recorded using KBr disks on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer with a DGTS detector (32 scans). A PerkinElmer STA 6000 was used for thermal analyses under air atmosphere, with a heating rate of 5 °C·min–1 in the temperature range of 50–800 °C. A Bruker-D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer was used for powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The luminescent performance was examined with the powdered solid samples on an Edinburgh FLS 920 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. Two instruments of J-810­(S) and Olis DM245TB spectropolarimeter (KBr pellets) are employed to obtain the electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra of 1-r, 2-r, 3-r, and 4-r at room temperature. The SHG intensities were measured by a Spectra Physics Quanta Ray Prolab 170 Nd:YAG laser with microcrystalline samples relative to urea, using the first-harmonics output of 1064 nm with a pulse width of 10 ns and a repetition rate of 10 Hz.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

The chemical reagents were from Aladdin and used in the reactions without any treatment or purification. A PerkinElmer 2400 elemental analyzer is used for elemental analyses of the compounds. The IR spectra were recorded using KBr disks on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer with a DGTS detector (32 scans). A PerkinElmer STA 6000 was used for thermal analyses under air atmosphere, with a heating rate of 5 °C⋅min-1 in the temperature range of 50-800 °C. A Bruker-D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer was used for powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The luminescent performance was examined with the powdered solid samples on an Edinburgh FLS 920 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. Two instruments of J-810(S) and Olis DM245TB spectropolarimeter (KBr pellets) are employed to obtain the electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra of 1-r, 2-r, 3-r, and 4-r at room temperature. The SHG intensities were measured by a Spectra Physics Quanta Ray Prolab 170 Nd:YAG laser with microcrystalline samples relative to urea, using the first-harmonics output of 1064 nm with a pulse width of 10 ns and a repetition rate of 10 Hz.

elements.content: Methyl 3,5-dihydroxybenzoate (1, 1.68 g, MW = 168.1, 0.01 mol), l-(−)-lactic acid methyl ester ((S)-methyl lactate) or d-(−)-lactic acid methyl ester ((R)-methyl lactate) (2, 2.2 g, MW = 104.1, 0.02 mol), and triphenylphosphine (PPh3, 5.8 g, MW = 262.3, 0.02 mol) were dissolved in 50 mL of tetrahydrofuran, to which diethyl diazocarboxylate (DEAD) solution (0.022 mol in 10 mL THF) was added dropwise over 10 min at 0 °C (). The mixture was concentrated after stirring for 3 h under the same temperature. The resulting residue was then purified with the method of column chromatography (silica gel eluted by the mixed solvent of 20% ethyl acetate and petroleum ether). Compound 3 was then obtained as a yellowish solid (2.5 g, MW = 340.1, 0.0073 mol, 73%, >97% ee). HPLC with a chiral column was used to determine the enantiomeric excess (DAICEL CHIRALCELAD-H, 10.0% 2-propanol in hexane, 1.0 mL/min). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 7.25 (s, 2H), 7.14 (d, J = 2.3, 16H), 6.65 (t, J = 2.3, 8H), 4.74 (q, J = 6.8, 17H), 4.21 (pd, J = 7.5, 3.6, 34H), 3.85 (s, 24H), 1.59 (d, J = 6.8, 50H), 1.24 (t, J = 7.1, 51H), 0.05 (s, 11H), 0.02 (s, 1H).

elements.content: Dimethyl-2,2′-((5-(methoxycarbonyl)-1,3-phenylene)­bis­(oxy))­dipropanoate (3a or 3b, 6.8g, MW = 340.1, 0.02 mol), methanol (20 mL), water (90 mL), and solid sodium hydroxide (3.6 g, 0.09 mol) were added into a flask. The resulting mixture was heated at 55 °C for 12 h with stirring; then concentrated HCl in an ice bath was added to the solution until a pH value of about 1–2 was achieved. The resulting solution was extracted by ethyl acetate to give a white solid 4a or 4b (4.76 g, MW = 298, 0.0159 mol, 80%): 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO) δ = 13.07 (s, 41H), 7.00 (d, J = 2.3, 28H), 6.65 (t, J = 2.3, 14H), 4.87 (q, J = 6.7, 29H), 3.32 (s, 24H), 2.51 (dt, J = 3.5, 1.7, 84H), 1.66 (s, 1H), 1.51 (d, J = 6.7, 84H), 0.01 (s, 9H).

elements.content: Nd­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.1 mmol, 44 mg), (R,R)-H3L (0.1 mmol, 30 mg), distilled water (8 mL), and acetonitrile (2 mL) were mixed and kept stirring for 10 min. After being transferred to and sealed in a 23 mL Teflon reactor, the vessel was heated at 140 °C for 72 h and was subsequently allowed to cool to about 25 °C. Purple crystals (60.7%, based on Nd) were collected after washing with water. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for Nd2C26H36O23 (1005.03): C 31.07, H 3.61. Found: C 30.95, H 3.42. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3395 (m), 1569 (s), 1466 (w), 1406 (s), 1286 (s), 1165 (m), 1091 (w), 1044 (m), 871 (w), 786 (m), 676 (w).

elements.content: Single crystals of complexes 1–4 were chosen with an optical microscope to collect their X-ray diffraction data. The intensity data of the crystals were obtained on a Oxford Xcalibur Gemini Ultra diffractometer or a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID imaging plate diffractometer, both using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) under room temperature. Data processing was conducted with the SAINT software. The complex structures were solved by direct methods, and all non-hydrogen atoms are anisotropically refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with the SHELXTL-97 program. TOPOS software was used for the topological analysis. The corresponding crystallographic data are shown in . The selected bond lengths of the eight complexes are presented in Table S1 (Supporting Information).

Reacting H3L with the corresponding lanthanide nitrates, crystals of 1–4 were obtained at 140 °C for 3 days under hydrothermal conditions. However, the mechanisms for the crystal formation in the sealed reaction vessel are still in the exploration phase currently. Many mechanisms could only be reasoned and proposed by the results. In the hydrothermal process with a specific condition, many factors could have an impact on the formation of the complexes, such as the type of organic linkers, the counteranions, the original concentration of reactants, pH value of the solution, etc. For complexes 1–4, the reaction solvent and pH behave as two key factors. No suitable product is obtained in methanol, ethanol, DMF, DMA, or pure water as solvent. Moreover, when pH value was more than 4.0 or less than 1.5, small crystals were obtained with powder at the same time. The complexes of Nd (1), Sm (2), Eu (3), and Tb (4) have been tested by PXRD, infrared spectroscopy (IR), and elemental analysis (EA). The phase purity of the obtained products is confirmed. Considering that complexes 1–4 demonstrate only two different structure types, the structural details of 1-r and 4-r are described below as representatives.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Reacting H3L with the corresponding lanthanide nitrates, crystals of 1-4 were obtained at 140 °C for 3 days under hydrothermal conditions. However, the mechanisms for the crystal formation in the sealed reaction vessel are still in the exploration phase currently. Many mechanisms could only be reasoned and proposed by the results. In the hydrothermal process with a specific condition, many factors could have an impact on the formation of the complexes, such as the type of organic linkers, the counteranions, the original concentration of reactants, pH value of the solution, etc. For complexes 1-4, the reaction solvent and pH behave as two key factors. No suitable product is obtained in methanol, ethanol, DMF, DMA, or pure water as solvent. Moreover, when pH value was more than 4.0 or less than 1.5, small crystals were obtained with powder at the same time. The complexes of Nd (1), Sm (2), Eu (3), and Tb (4) have been tested by PXRD, infrared spectroscopy (IR), and elemental analysis (EA). The phase purity of the obtained products is confirmed. Considering that complexes 1-4 demonstrate only two different structure types, the structural details of 1-r and 4-r are described below as representatives.

elements.content: According to the analysis results from single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD), the complexes 1-r/1-s are structurally isomorphous, so only the structure of 1-r will be discussed in detail. The results reveal that complexes 1-r/1-s with interesting 3D HMOF structures crystallize in a chiral space group P21212, and the Flack parameters of 1-r/1-s are 0.01(2) and −0.01(2), respectively. One asymmetric unit of 1-r contains two crystallographically independent [Nd]3+ (Nd1, Nd2) ions, two half-occupied [L]3– moieties, one fully deprotonated [L]3–, and three coordinated and four guest water molecules. As shown in a, the Nd1 ion is surrounded by eight oxygen atoms from six different [L]3– ligands, displaying a dodecahedral coordination geometry. With a coordination geometry similar to that of Nd1, the Nd2 ion is coordinated to five oxygen atoms from five different [L]3– ligands and three oxygen atoms from three water molecules. The Nd–O bond lengths are from 2.288(7) to 2.713(7) Å and the O–Nd–O bond angles are within the range of 49.21(18)–156.70(19)°, which are all in reasonable ranges. The three carboxylate groups of [L]3– employ chelating bidentate, bridging bidentate, and bridging tridentate coordination modes, respectively. The carboxyl groups and Nd ions link to each other to form right-hand {−Nd1–Nd1–Nd2–Nd2−} n helical chains along the a axis (b), which are parallel to each other with the same handedness and a screw pitch of 12.841(4) Å. Synchronously, four neighboring helical chains along the a axis eventually result in a 3D homochiral framework. According to a topological analysis, the structure of 1-r can be described as a 5,5,6,6,6-net with a point syambol of (45·65)­(48·67)­(49·65·8)­(49·6) (d), since the [L]3– ligands exhibiting two different modes could serve as 5- or 6-connected nodes (structures A and C in ).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Description

Structure Description of {[Nd2((L)2H2O)3]⋅4H2O} n  (1-r)

According to the analysis results from single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD), the complexes 1-r/1-s are structurally isomorphous, so only the structure of 1-r will be discussed in detail. The results reveal that complexes 1-r/1-s with interesting 3D HMOF structures crystallize in a chiral space group P21212, and the Flack parameters of 1-r/1-s are 0.01(2) and -0.01(2), respectively. One asymmetric unit of 1-r contains two crystallographically independent [Nd]3+ (Nd1, Nd2) ions, two half-occupied [L]3- moieties, one fully deprotonated [L]3-, and three coordinated and four guest water molecules. As shown in a, the Nd1 ion is surrounded by eight oxygen atoms from six different [L]3- ligands, displaying a dodecahedral coordination geometry. With a coordination geometry similar to that of Nd1, the Nd2 ion is coordinated to five oxygen atoms from five different [L]3- ligands and three oxygen atoms from three water molecules. The Nd-O bond lengths are from 2.288(7) to 2.713(7) Å and the O-Nd-O bond angles are within the range of 49.21(18)-156.70(19)°, which are all in reasonable ranges. The three carboxylate groups of [L]3- employ chelating bidentate, bridging bidentate, and bridging tridentate coordination modes, respectively. The carboxyl groups and Nd ions link to each other to form right-hand {-Nd1-Nd1-Nd2-Nd2-} n  helical chains along the a axis (b), which are parallel to each other with the same handedness and a screw pitch of 12.841(4) Å. Synchronously, four neighboring helical chains along the a axis eventually result in a 3D homochiral framework. According to a topological analysis, the structure of 1-r can be described as a 5,5,6,6,6-net with a point syambol of (45⋅65)(48⋅67)(49⋅65⋅8)(49⋅6) (d), since the [L]3- ligands exhibiting two different modes could serve as 5- or 6-connected nodes (structures A and C in ).

elements.content: X-ray diffraction results indicate that 2–4 are isomorphous, exhibiting a 3D architecture based on dinuclear Ln clusters (Ln = Sm3+, Eu3+, Tb3+) by [L]3– connectors. Therefore, the structure of 4-r is discussed in detail as the representative. As a showns, an asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent [Tb]3+ (Tb1, Tb2) ions, two crystallographically independent and fully deprotonated [L]3–, and two coordinated and four guest water molecules. The eight-coordinated Tb1 ion with dodecahedral coordination geometry is coordinated to eight oxygen atoms from six different [L]3–. The Tb2 ion also exhibits the same dodecahedral coordination geometry defined by six oxygen atoms from five different [L]3– ligands and two oxygen atoms from two water molecules. The Tb–O bond lengths are in the reasonable range of 2.257(4)–2.632(4) Å, and the O–Tb–O bond angles are from 51.58(11)° to 152.19(13)°. Similar to the complexes 1-r/1-s, complexes 2–4 posssess helical chains along the b axis (b), constructed by {−Tb1–Tb2–Tb1–Tb2−} n repeating units. The neighboring {−Tb1–Tb2–Tb1–Tb2−} n helical chains are linked together by three carboxylate groups from [L]3– in a bidentate bridging μ2-mode, giving rise to an edge-sharing dinuclear subunit [Tb2O16] with a Tb–Tb distance of 4.131(7)­Å. These dinuclear building blocks are interconnected through the μ6-η2:η2:η2 and μ5-η1:η2:η2 for [L]3– ligand connectors forming a 3D framework (c). As described above, for 2–4, if each Tb dimer connecting to seven [L]3– ligands was considered as a 7-connected node and the H3L molecules were taken as a 3-connected node and a 4-connected node, the structures of complexes 2–4 could be expressed as a 3,4,7-connected net with a point symbol (4·62)­(44·62)­(48·611·82) (d). And the [L]3– ligands exhibiting two different modes could be regarded as 5- or 6-connected nodes (structures B and C in ).

Structure Description of {[Ln2(L)2(H2O)2]⋅4H2O} n  {Ln = Sm (2), Eu (3), Tb (4)}

X-ray diffraction results indicate that 2-4 are isomorphous, exhibiting a 3D architecture based on dinuclear Ln clusters (Ln = Sm3+, Eu3+, Tb3+) by [L]3- connectors. Therefore, the structure of 4-r is discussed in detail as the representative. As a showns, an asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent [Tb]3+ (Tb1, Tb2) ions, two crystallographically independent and fully deprotonated [L]3-, and two coordinated and four guest water molecules. The eight-coordinated Tb1 ion with dodecahedral coordination geometry is coordinated to eight oxygen atoms from six different [L]3-. The Tb2 ion also exhibits the same dodecahedral coordination geometry defined by six oxygen atoms from five different [L]3- ligands and two oxygen atoms from two water molecules. The Tb-O bond lengths are in the reasonable range of 2.257(4)-2.632(4) Å, and the O-Tb-O bond angles are from 51.58(11)° to 152.19(13)°. Similar to the complexes 1-r/1-s, complexes 2-4 posssess helical chains along the b axis (b), constructed by {-Tb1-Tb2-Tb1-Tb2-} n  repeating units. The neighboring {-Tb1-Tb2-Tb1-Tb2-} n  helical chains are linked together by three carboxylate groups from [L]3- in a bidentate bridging μ2-mode, giving rise to an edge-sharing dinuclear subunit [Tb2O16] with a Tb-Tb distance of 4.131(7)Å. These dinuclear building blocks are interconnected through the μ6-η2:η2:η2 and μ5-η1:η2:η2 for [L]3- ligand connectors forming a 3D framework (c). As described above, for 2-4, if each Tb dimer connecting to seven [L]3- ligands was considered as a 7-connected node and the H3L molecules were taken as a 3-connected node and a 4-connected node, the structures of complexes 2-4 could be expressed as a 3,4,7-connected net with a point symbol (4⋅62)(44⋅62)(48⋅611⋅82) (d). And the [L]3- ligands exhibiting two different modes could be regarded as 5- or 6-connected nodes (structures B and C in ).

elements.content: The structural difference between the two frameworks might originate from the effect of lanthanide contraction, with the helical repeating units changing from {−Nd1–Nd1–Nd2–Nd2−} n in complex 1 to {−Tb1–Tb2–Tb1–Tb2−} n in complex 4. The different cationic radii and bridging modes of ligands caused the formation of channels with different size in the final 3D frameworks. The effective solvent accessible volumes of complexes 1r–4r are estimated to be about 24.3%, 23.8%, 23.3%, and 22.1% per unit cell as calculated by PLATON.

The different cationic radii and bridging modes of ligands caused the formation of channels with different size in the final 3D frameworks. The effective solvent accessible volumes of complexes 1r-4r are estimated to be about 24.3%, 23.8%, 23.3%, and 22.1% per unit cell as calculated by PLATON.

elements.content: For further confirming the phase purity of the crystalline products 1–4, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis has been conducted. The experimental XRD patterns corroborate well the simulated ones derived from crystal data, confirming the purity of the crystal samples. The preferred orientation of the crystals might lead to the different intensity demonstrated in the PXRD patterns comparison (Figure S1, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and Thermogravimetric Analysis

For further confirming the phase purity of the crystalline products 1-4, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis has been conducted. The experimental XRD patterns corroborate well the simulated ones derived from crystal data, confirming the purity of the crystal samples. The preferred orientation of the crystals might lead to the different intensity demonstrated in the PXRD patterns comparison (Figure S1, Supporting Information).

elements.content: In order to have a good understanding about the stability of the complexes, their thermal stability was ascertained by TGA (Figure S2). The single crystals of 1–4 are used for TGA measurements under air atmosphere. For complex 1-r, the 7.63% weight loss occurring between 50 and 176 °C is attributed to the loss of four lattice water molecules (theoretical 7.2%). The following gradual weight loss of 5.37% in the temperature range of 176–384 °C could be ascribed to the release of the three coordinated water molecules (theoretical 5.4%). The complex framework collapses at 384 °C. Complexes 2–4 demonstrate similar thermal behaviors as they are isostructual. Therefore, only complex 4-r is discussed in detail as the representative. The framework of 4-r with two steps of weight losses could be stable up to 337 °C. In the first step of 50–172 °C, four lattice water molecules were released (weight loss measured 7.38%, theoretical 7.08%). The 3.38% weight loss in the 172–337 °C range is due to the expelling of the remaining coordinated water molecules (theoretical 3.54%).

elements.content: As reported previously, many Sm­(III), Eu­(III), and Tb­(III) complexes display excellent luminescent properties; therefore, the photoluminescence of complexes 2-r, 3-r, and 4-r and their lifetimes were investigated. Excited at 420 nm, characteristic sharp bands of Sm3+ are found at 562, 596, 642, and 700 nm, which could be ascribed to the 4G5/2 → 6H J (J = 5/2, 7/2, 9/2, 11/2) transitions (a). Among these bands, the intensity of emission at 596 nm (4G5/2 → 6H7/2) is the strongest.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

As reported previously, many Sm(III), Eu(III), and Tb(III) complexes display excellent luminescent properties; therefore, the photoluminescence of complexes 2-r, 3-r, and 4-r and their lifetimes were investigated. Excited at 420 nm, characteristic sharp bands of Sm3+ are found at 562, 596, 642, and 700 nm, which could be ascribed to the 4G5/2 → 6H J  (J = 5/2, 7/2, 9/2, 11/2) transitions (a). Among these bands, the intensity of emission at 596 nm (4G5/2 → 6H7/2) is the strongest.

elements.content: Solid-state luminescence spectra of the complexes of 2-r, 3-r, and 4-r under excitation at 420, 394, and 336 nm at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 3  Solid-state luminescence spectra of the complexes of 2-r, 3-r, and 4-r under excitation at 420, 394, and 336 nm at room temperature.

elements.content: Excited at 394 nm, complex 3 with Eu3+ exhibits a bright red luminescence behavior (b). Measured in the 520–800 nm range, the ambient-temperature emission spectrum of 3 displays four major peaks, namely, 5D0 → 7F1 (592 nm), 5D0 → 7F2 (616 nm), 5D0 → 7F3 (652 nm), and 5D0 → 7F4 (698 nm). The 5D0 → 7F2 transition allowed by electric dipole is hypersensitive to the environment in the vicinity of Eu3+ ion, while the 5D0 → 7F1 transition is insensitive to the site symmetry as a magnetic dipole. Compared with the 5D0 → 7F1 transition, 5D0 → 7F2 transition demonstrates a stronger intensity, suggesting the absence of an inversion center for Eu3+ ion. This accords with the fact that the Eu3+ ion in complex 3 occupies a site without an inversion center. Upon excitation at 336 nm, complex 4 exhibits characteristic Tb­(III) emissions at 490 nm (5D4 → 7F6), 545 nm (very strong 5D4 → 7F5), 586 nm (5D4 → 7F4), and 622 nm (5D4 → 7F3) (c). The most intense transition of 5D4 → 7F5 leads to strong green luminescence for the crystal sample.

The 5D0 → 7F2 transition allowed by electric dipole is hypersensitive to the environment in the vicinity of Eu3+ ion, while the 5D0 → 7F1 transition is insensitive to the site symmetry as a magnetic dipole. Compared with the 5D0 → 7F1 transition, 5D0 → 7F2 transition demonstrates a stronger intensity, suggesting the absence of an inversion center for Eu3+ ion. Upon excitation at 336 nm, complex 4 exhibits characteristic Tb(III) emissions at 490 nm (5D4 → 7F6), 545 nm (very strong 5D4 → 7F5), 586 nm (5D4 → 7F4), and 622 nm (5D4 → 7F3) (c). The most intense transition of 5D4 → 7F5 leads to strong green luminescence for the crystal sample.

elements.content: For complexes 2-r, 3-r, and 4-r, their luminescence decay curves were obtained at room temperature. It is found that the decay curves are fitted well into a single-exponential function as I = I 0 exp­(−t/τ), which suggests that the sites of Eu­(III) in the structure are in a single chemical environment. Complex 3 also demonstrates a corresponding lifetime of about 0.490 ms. For complexes 2 and 4, their decay curves can be well fit into a double-exponential function as I = A + B 1 exp­(−t/τ1) + B 2 exp­(−t/τ2) (where τ1 and τ2 are the fast and slow components of the luminescent lifetimes and A, B 1, and B 2 are the fitting parameters). In reported Ln­(III) coordination compounds, similar results have been found. The lifetimes for 4G5/2 → 6H7/2 of the Sm­(III) ion were calculated to be τ1= 0.011 ms and τ2= 0.148 ms. Therefore, based on τ = (B 1τ1 2 + B 2τ2 2)/(B 1τ1+ B 2τ2), the average lifetime of 4G5/2 → 6H7/2 for the Sm­(III) ion can be calculated to be 1.173 ms (fitting parameters B 1 = 2174.24 and B 2 = 62.83) and that of Tb­(III) ion is 1.146 ms (fitting parameters B 1 = 11793.80 and B 2 = 39011.13). The above results prove that the H3L ligand is able to sensitize the Ln3+ emitter; which can serve as a host for encapsulating Ln3+ ions demonstrating tunable fluorescence emission.

For complexes 2 and 4, their decay curves can be well fit into a double-exponential function as I = A + B 1 exp(-t/τ1) + B 2 exp(-t/τ2) (where τ1 and τ2 are the fast and slow components of the luminescent lifetimes and A, B 1, and B 2 are the fitting parameters). In reported Ln(III) coordination compounds, similar results have been found. The lifetimes for 4G5/2 → 6H7/2 of the Sm(III) ion were calculated to be τ1= 0.011 ms and τ2= 0.148 ms. Therefore, based on τ = (B 1τ1 2 + B 2τ2 2)/(B 1τ1+ B 2τ2), the average lifetime of 4G5/2 → 6H7/2 for the Sm(III) ion can be calculated to be 1.173 ms (fitting parameters B 1 = 2174.24 and B 2 = 62.83) and that of Tb(III) ion is 1.146 ms (fitting parameters B 1 = 11793.80 and B 2 = 39011.13). The above results prove that the H3L ligand is able to sensitize the Ln3+ emitter; which can serve as a host for encapsulating Ln3+ ions demonstrating tunable fluorescence emission.

elements.content:
To further demonstrate the homochirality of the complexes, solid-state electronic circular dichroism (ECD) analysis has been conducted (Figure S4).

The ECD spectrum of the (R,R)-H3L ligand shows a positive signal at 270 nm, and the (S,S)-H3L ligand has the opposite signal at 270 nm. Complex 1-r exhibits a positive signal at 309 nm; comparatively, complex 1-s displays an opposite signal at 306 nm. Complex 2-r shows a positive signal at 314 nm and an opposite signal at around 279 nm, and 2-s has the opposite signals at 320 and 279 nm. Furthermore, complexes 3-r and 3-s show opposite signals at 314 and 278 nm, respectively. For the crystal sample of 4-r, its ECD spectrum displays a positive signal at 314 nm and a negative signal at 274 nm. Meanwhile, a mirror image is observed for 4-s. The solid-state ECD confirms the presence of enantiomers for the four pairs of complexes.

elements.content: Considering that chiral ligands could provide guaranteed homochiral crystallization of a complex in a noncentrosymmetric point group and so our complexes have a potential application as NLO-active materials, their second-order NLO properties have been determined by the Kurtz–Perry method at room temperature. Preliminary experimental results show that 1-r, 2-r, 3-r, and 4-r are 0.5, 0.4, 0.7, and 0.6 times the value of urea, respectively. Complexes 1–4 display lower SHG response than that of urea, which might be explained from the aspect of the lacking of a donor–acceptor system originating from the influences of helical structures.

elements.content: It was reported that nitro compounds could influence the fluorescence of coordination polymers, particularly the compound trinitrobenzene (TNB) showing signficant quenching behavior. Sm3+, Eu3+, and Tb3+emit orange, red, and green, respectively, upon adequate excitation, which are easy to observe. We use complex 4-r as a representative to detect nitroaromatic explosives. A batch of suspensions of complex 4-r was prepared by dispersing it in a DMSO solution, which enables nitro-containing compounds to be closely adhered to the particles surface of complex 4, facilitating probable host–guest interaction. Luminescence quenching is related to the electron-withdrawing −NO2 group. Here, electron transfer from the electron-donating complexes to TNB with high electron deficiency can take place upon excitation, causing the fluorescence quenching of the complex. As indicates, the luminescence intensity of complex 4-r significantly decreases when the TNB concentration gradually increases. Similar quenching phenomena were reported in previous works.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Identification of Nitro Compounds

It was reported that nitro compounds could influence the fluorescence of coordination polymers, particularly the compound trinitrobenzene (TNB) showing signficant quenching behavior. Sm3+, Eu3+, and Tb3+emit orange, red, and green, respectively, upon adequate excitation, which are easy to observe. We use complex 4-r as a representative to detect nitroaromatic explosives. A batch of suspensions of complex 4-r was prepared by dispersing it in a DMSO solution, which enables nitro-containing compounds to be closely adhered to the particles surface of complex 4, facilitating probable host-guest interaction. Luminescence quenching is related to the electron-withdrawing -NO2 group. Here, electron transfer from the electron-donating complexes to TNB with high electron deficiency can take place upon excitation, causing the fluorescence quenching of the complex. As  indicates, the luminescence intensity of complex 4-r significantly decreases when the TNB concentration gradually increases. Similar quenching phenomena were reported in previous works.

elements.content: In summary, we have presented here four pairs of unprecedented families of lanthanide-based coordination polymers based on 2,2′-((5-(methoxycarbonyl)-1,3-phenylene)­bis­(oxy))­dipropanoic acid (H3L). Complexes 1–4 display two types of 3D metal–organic networks with different dinuclear Ln secondary building units, which could be ascribed to Ln contraction and different coordination modes demonstrated by H3L. Moreover, the SHG investigation indicates the complexes 1-r, 2-r, 3-r, and 4-r display SHG efficiencies 0.4, 0.5, 0.7, and 0.6 times that of urea. The luminescence properties of 2–4 have been examined, and the results indicated the presence of high fluorescence lifetime. The Tb-MOF shows excellent fluorescence properties, with an especially significant quenching effect toward traces of nitroaromatic compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have presented here four pairs of unprecedented families of lanthanide-based coordination polymers based on 2,2'-((5-(methoxycarbonyl)-1,3-phenylene)bis(oxy))dipropanoic acid (H3L). Complexes 1-4 display two types of 3D metal-organic networks with different dinuclear Ln secondary building units, which could be ascribed to Ln contraction and different coordination modes demonstrated by H3L. Moreover, the SHG investigation indicates the complexes 1-r, 2-r, 3-r, and 4-r display SHG efficiencies 0.4, 0.5, 0.7, and 0.6 times that of urea. The luminescence properties of 2-4 have been examined, and the results indicated the presence of high fluorescence lifetime. The Tb-MOF shows excellent fluorescence properties, with an especially significant quenching effect toward traces of nitroaromatic compounds.

Methyl 3,5-dihydroxybenzoate (1, 1.68 g, MW = 168.1, 0.01 mol), l-(−)-lactic acid methyl ester ((S)-methyl lactate) or d-(−)-lactic acid methyl ester ((R)-methyl lactate) (2, 2.2 g, MW = 104.1, 0.02 mol), and triphenylphosphine (PPh3, 5.8 g, MW = 262.3, 0.02 mol) were dissolved in 50 mL of tetrahydrofuran, to which diethyl diazocarboxylate (DEAD) solution (0.022 mol in 10 mL THF) was added dropwise over 10 min at 0 °C (). The mixture was concentrated after stirring for 3 h under the same temperature. The resulting residue was then purified with the method of column chromatography (silica gel eluted by the mixed solvent of 20% ethyl acetate and petroleum ether). Compound 3 was then obtained as a yellowish solid (2.5 g, MW = 340.1, 0.0073 mol, 73%, >97% ee). HPLC with a chiral column was used to determine the enantiomeric excess (DAICEL CHIRALCELAD-H, 10.0% 2-propanol in hexane, 1.0 mL/min). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 7.25 (s, 2H), 7.14 (d, J = 2.3, 16H), 6.65 (t, J = 2.3, 8H), 4.74 (q, J = 6.8, 17H), 4.21 (pd, J = 7.5, 3.6, 34H), 3.85 (s, 24H), 1.59 (d, J = 6.8, 50H), 1.24 (t, J = 7.1, 51H), 0.05 (s, 11H), 0.02 (s, 1H).

The resulting mixture was heated at 55 °C for 12 h with stirring; then concentrated HCl in an ice bath was added to the solution until a pH value of about 1–2 was achieved. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for Tb2C26H34O22 (1016.39): C 30.72, H 3.37. Found: C 30.74, H 3.39. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3422(m), 1566 (s), 1470 (w), 1412 (s), 1289 (s), 1169 (m), 1131(w), 1094 (w), 1045 (m), 878 (w), 827 (w), 786 (w), 749 (w), 680 (w).

Synthesis of {[Tb2(L)2(H2O)2]⋅4H2O} n  (4-s)

The same procedure as that for 4-r was conducted except that (S,S)-H3L was used. Colorless crystals (62.9%, based on Tb) were obtained by filtration. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for Tb2C26H34O22 (1016.39): C 30.72, H 3.37. Found: C 30.73, H 3.38. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3420 (m), 1569 (s), 1466 (w), 1410 (s), 1290 (s), 1165 (m), 1134(w), 1094 (w), 1045 (m), 878 (w), 827 (w), 789 (w), 754 (w), 687 (w).

cln_elements.content:
In order to have a good understanding about the stability of the complexes, their thermal stability was ascertained by TGA (Figure S2). The single crystals of 1–4 are used for TGA measurements under air atmosphere. For complex 1-r, the 7.63% weight loss occurring between 50 and 176 °C is attributed to the loss of four lattice water molecules (theoretical 7.2%). The following gradual weight loss of 5.37% in the temperature range of 176–384 °C could be ascribed to the release of the three coordinated water molecules (theoretical 5.4%). The complex framework collapses at 384 °C. Complexes 2–4 demonstrate similar thermal behaviors as they are isostructual. Therefore, only complex 4-r is discussed in detail as the representative. The framework of 4-r with two steps of weight losses could be stable up to 337 °C. In the first step of 50–172 °C, four lattice water molecules were released (weight loss measured 7.38%, theoretical 7.08%). The 3.38% weight loss in the 172–337 °C range is due to the expelling of the remaining coordinated water molecules (theoretical 3.54%).

Photoluminescent Properties

As reported previously, many Sm­(III), Eu­(III), and Tb­(III) complexes display excellent luminescent properties; therefore, the photoluminescence of complexes 2-r, 3-r, and 4-r and their lifetimes were investigated. Excited at 420 nm, characteristic sharp bands of Sm3+ are found at 562, 596, 642, and 700 nm, which could be ascribed to the 4G5/2 → 6H J (J = 5/2, 7/2, 9/2, 11/2) transitions (a). Among these bands, the intensity of emission at 596 nm (4G5/2 → 6H7/2) is the strongest.
